tossups.question: A play named for this character inspired Modest Mussorgsky's "Song of the Flea." In the fourth act of an opera named for this character, a military company sings the march "Gloire immortelle de nos aïeux," (glo-AHR ee-mor-TELL duh "nose" "EYE"-euh) which became known as the "Soldiers' Chorus." At his death, Ferruccio Busoni left an unfinished opera named for this character, who, in a "dramatic legend," listens to the Rákóczi March (“rah-KOE-chay march”) before retiring to his (*) study. In two 19th century French operas named for this character, he falls in love with a woman named Marguerite. Charles Gounod wrote a popular opera about this character, whose "damnation" is the subject of an opera by Hector Berlioz. For 10 points, name this mythical German scholar who sells his soul to the Devil for youth and knowledge.
tossups.answer: Faust [or The Damnation of Faust; or Doktor Faust]

tossups.question: A modification to this practice was argued for in a sermon given on Abraham Lincoln's birthday by George MacPherson Docherty. Harlan Fisk Stone argued that states could enforce this practice in the Minersville case. This practice was created as part of an 1892 Columbus Day essay contest held by the magazine Youth's Companion. In 1943, Jehovah's Witnesses argued that engaging in this practice constituted (*) veneration in the landmark case West Virginia vs. Barnette. Francis Bellamy is credited with creating this practice, and the Knights of Columbus lobbied the Eisenhower administration to add the phrase "under god" to it in 1954. For 10 points, name this action which American schoolchildren do in the morning while addressing the flag.
tossups.answer: Pledge of Allegiance [or pledging allegiance to the American flag; accept answers like reciting the Pledge of Allegiance or forcing Jehovah's Witnesses to pledge allegiance to the flag; prompt on saluting the American flag by asking "while performing what other action?"]

tossups.question: Sodium borohydride breaks an intermediate containing an acetate of this metal in an anti addition of a hydroxyl group. This element and its chloride are contained in a standard reference electrode named for being saturated; those electrodes contain this element's chloride calomel. Hydrochloric acid and an alloy of zinc and this metal convert carbonyls to alkanes in the Clemmensen reduction. This element tends to form poly·cat·ions, the most notable of which contains (*) two elements and a net charge of 2. This element’s primary ore is cinnabar. The non-metric "torr" unit was originally defined as one millimeter of this metal, which is often used to report air pressure. Amalgams are alloys of, for 10 points, what metal, which is liquid at room temperature?
tossups.answer: mercury [or Hg; accept oxymercuration-demercuration or millimeters of mercury]

tossups.question: A poet who used this language for the oft-quoted poem "Night, street, lamp, drugstore" wrote the line "black night / white snow" to open a long poem that ends with a vision of Christ in a snowstorm. A poem in this language notes that "today I have much to do: I must kill off memory." The Apostles are likened to the title soldiers of "The Twelve," a poem from this language's (*) Silver Age. A poet in this language asks "Can you describe this?" in the section "Instead of a Preface" from a poem about her son's imprisonment, titled "Requiem." A man dances with the wrong girl at a name-day ball in a poem in this language, in which a duel ends with Lensky being killed by Eugene Onegin ("on-YAY-ghin"). For 10 points, name this language used by Aleksandr Pushkin.
tossups.answer: Russian [or russkiy] ("Night, street, lamp, drugstore" and "The Twelve" are by Aleksandr Blok; "Requiem" is by Anna Akhmatova)

"Karamojo" Bell succeeded in this activity over 1,000 times in an African variant of it that focused on the (*) "Big Five." A story about a president showing mercy during this activity in 1902 led Morris Michtom to create a popular children's toy. tossups.question: According to legend, this god appeared to the runner Pheidippides (“fay-DIP-uh-deez”) on Mount Parthenius and promised to help the Athenians at the Battle of Marathon. Early Christians held that Jesus' death occurred at the same time as an incident recorded by Plutarch, in which the sailor Thamus received news about this god. In that story, a mysterious voice cried out that this "great" god was dead. After (*) Tmolus (“tuh-MOLE-us”) judged this god the loser in a contest, King Midas protested the decision, and, for favoring this god, was given donkey ears. To escape this god, the nymph Syrinx asked to be transformed into a clump of reeds, which this god used to create a set of pipes. For 10 points, name this Greek nature god who possessed the horns and lower body of a goat.
tossups.answer: Pan

tossups.question: A composer from this non-Caribbean country created the "Sleng Teng" riddim (“rid-dum”) commonly used in reggae music. This country was home to an executive whose love for a 1951 recording of Ludwig van Beethoven's Ninth Symphony led to the Red Book music standard being increased to 74 minutes. An instrument maker from this country commercialized John Chowning's patent on Frequency Modulation (*) Synthesis for devices such as the DX7 Synthesizer. In the early 1990s, Brother Industries in this country established a MIDI (“mid-EE”) streaming service to enhance a sing-along format popular with salarymen. tossups.answer: Japan (the "Sleng Teng" riddim was composed by Okuda Hiroko at Casio)

tossups.question: Beta coronavirus egress relies on hijacking these organelles for secretion as opposed to normal biosynthetic secretion, which additionally inhibits MHC-II (“M-H-C-2”) presentation. Legionella pneumo·phila causes membrane remodeling to prevent one structure's recognition by this organelle. The TACO protein of myco·bacterium inhibits this organelle's ability to fuse with a (*) phagosome, after which a macrophage would normally undergo the respiratory burst. tossups.question: In a novel by an author with this last name, a character makes a deal with The Gentleman with the Thistledown Hair to resurrect Lady Pole. An author with this last name wrote a novel where poverty, war, and sickness are eliminated by the Overlords, aliens who look like devils. An author with this surname depicted a rivalry between two magicians in Regency-era England in her novel (*) Jonathan Strange & Mr. Norrell. An author with this surname wrote Childhood's End, as well as a novel that begins with the man-ape Moon-watcher learning to use tools. tossups.question: Local examples of these features, which correspond to infinite Lie ("lee") groups, are the basis of gauge theories. When one of these features vanishes, a Nambu-Goldstone boson appears, which can occur through the Higgs mechanism. A theory named for an extreme type of these features posits the existence of a fermion corresponding to each boson. Continuous examples of these features correspond to (*) conserved quantities by Noether's ("NUR-tuh's") theorem. All physical laws have one of these features called CPT, which exists when charge, parity and time are all simultaneously transformed. He's not Frank Sinatra, but Mary proclaims that the narrator will be played by "war-loving, dirty old men" like this man in the first chapter of Slaughterhouse-Five. This person's forces defeated heretics such as Musaylimah who refused to pay zakat during the Ridda Wars. tossups.question: Official documents limiting these people's ability to sell property usually used the acronym RPR to refer to them. Samuel Pepys ("peeps") regularly visited Threadneedle Street with his wife, one of these people. These people established Fort Caroline as part of a short-lived effort to colonize modern-day Florida. These people were forced to quarter troops in the Dragonnades ("drag-on-ahd") policy. Several colonies of these people were established by Admiral (*) Gaspard de Coligny ("gasp-AR de co-leeg-NEE"). These people were welcomed into Prussia via the Edict of Potsdam. Liberties granted to these people were curtailed following the 1627-1628 siege of La Rochelle. tossups.question: In one essay, Nora Ephron sarcastically complains that "I was probably the only person... that [this man] had not made a pass at" while working for him as an intern. This man is described as an "existential hero" in a long Esquire article by Norman Mailer titled "Superman Comes to the Supermarket." tossups.question: The antibiotic cef·i·dero·col binds to this element to enter bacteria via active transporters. Entero·bactin binds the plus 3 ion of this element with an extremely high affinity. Dietary forms of this element are reduced by du·o·de·nal cyto·chrome B to its di·valent form for transport. Hepcidin (“hepSIGH-din”) encourages the trapping of this element within macrophages and the liver during inflammation to limit its accessibility to bacteria. Bacteria release (*) siderophores (“sigh-DARE-oh-fours”) to scavenge this element. Lead poisoning symptoms resemble a deficiency of this element due to preventing this element's complex·ation by a porphyrin ring. Anemia can be caused by a deficiency of, for 10 points, what metal found in hemoglobin?
tossups.answer: iron

bonuses.leadin: Although this author scrapped a novel centered on Mexico City's Zocalo Plaza, she completed numerous other works set in the country, including the essay "Why I Write about Mexico." For 10 points each:

bonuses.leadin: Loren Lomasky's essay "Libertarianism at Twin Harvard" imagines a world where this man swaps political ideologies with his rival and colleague John Rawls. For 10 points each:

Lomasky's “Twin Rawls” argues that agents would pick a society with robust property rights and freedom of contract when choosing from behind a "veil of ignorance" in this hypothetical state.
“Twin Nozick”, in contrast, defends a social democratic "entitlement theory" based on the theory of natural rights found in this thinker's Two Treatises of Government.

bonuses.leadin: One of these devices that shut down in 2011 was named for its ability to impart energies over one teraelectronvolt. For 10 points each:
answers: particle accelerators [or particle colliders; accept Stanford Linear Accelerator]
Enrico Fermi [accept Fermilab or Enrico Fermi National Laboratory]
parts: Name these devices that include the Tevatron. Stanford operated a massive "linear" example of these devices until the 2000s.

The Tevatron was built at an Illinois "lab" named for this physicist. This Italian physicist built the Chicago Pile-1, the world's first nuclear reactor, under the stands of his university's football field.

Fermi's nuclear reactor work was continued not at Fermilab, but at this other national laboratory in Illinois. The world's first nuclear submarine, the USS Nautilus, was partly designed at this facility in Lemont.

bonuses.leadin: A type of these devices called the carruca likely developed in China in the 1st century CE. For 10 points each:
answers: plows [or ploughs; accept moldboard plow; prompt on ard]
no crops were grown in it [accept anything involving the field not being sown or planted or growing or was empty of crops]
Townshend (“TOWNS-ind”) [accept Charles Townshend or Turnip Townshend; accept Townshend Acts]
parts: Name these devices whose moldboard variety increased productivity in the Middle Ages.
Another way to improve agricultural productivity was the three-field crop rotation system, where one field was left fallow each year, meaning the field was in this state. A description is acceptable.

A brother-in-law of Robert Walpole with this last name earned the epithet "turnip" for advocating a turnipheavy crop rotation scheme. A later politician of this surname sponsored an act that established a Board of Commissioners in Boston to collect taxes prior to his early death.
answers_formatted: no crops were grown in it [accept anything involving the field not being sown or planted or growing or was empty of crops]

no crops were grown in it
anything involving the field not being sown

bonuses.leadin: Patients with PKU have an inability to metabolize this amino acid into tyrosine. For 10 points each:
answers: (artificial) sweetener [or sugar substitute; do not accept or prompt on “sugar”]
parts: Name this amino acid with a benzyl side chain.
A methyl ester of phenylalanine and aspartic acid, aspartame, is sold under the brand name Equal as one of these substances. Cyclamate and saccharin also are used as these substances.
Aspartame can undergo the Maillard (my-YAR) with this sort of sugar, which can perform a namesake reaction due to the presence of an aldehyde or hemi·a·cetal group in its open-chain form.
answers_formatted: sweetener [or sugar substitute; do not accept or prompt on "sugar"]

bonuses.leadin: A 1731 incident in which the Bishnoi sect was massacred for protecting one of these places inspired the later Chipko movement. For 10 points each:
answers: forests [or groves, woods, copses, or anything indicating a collection of trees; or wilderness]
threads [or strings; or cords; or yagnyopavita; or janeu; or jandhyam; or poonal; prompt on bracelets, talismans, or amulets]
mothers [or synonyms; accept Amma; prompt on parents]
parts: Name this sort of place that names the Aranyaka texts. In the third of the ashrama stages of life, vānaprastha (“VAH-nuh-pruh-stuh”), Brahmin men would go to live in this sort of place.

Chipko women adorned trees with these items, or rakhi, in reference to a festival in which girls place them on their brothers' wrists. "Twice-born" Brahmins wear a "sacred" one of these things over their shoulders.
Tree planting initiatives in India have also been led by the "hugging saint," whose followers refer to her as this family relation. Shiva's wife, Parvati, has this family relation to Ganesh.
answers_formatted: forests [or groves, woods, copses, or anything indicating a collection of trees; or wilderness]
threads [or strings; or cords; or yagnyopavita; or janeu; or jandhyam; or poonal; prompt on bracelets, talismans, or amulets]

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, identify the following about the varied writings of author T. C. Boyle.
answers: nudism [or naturism; accept answers like not wearing clothes]
parts: Boyle's first novel, Water Music, told of this real-life explorer and his fictional companion Ned Rise. This Scottish explorer died somewhere near Segou while leading his second expedition to explore the Niger River.
Boyle's 2003 novel Drop City ends with a violent climax on Halloween in this state, once referred to as “Seward’s Folly.”

The protagonists of Drop City engage in this practice, which was promoted in East Germany as "free body culture." The sport of miniten was invented at an adults-only colony for people engaging in this practice.

bonuses.leadin: H. P. Lovecraft noted that this story's title figure subsists solely on water and milk in his essay "Supernatural Horror in Literature." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this 1887 story often said to illustrate its syphilitic author's decline into madness. It depicts a character who burns his house and servants in order to kill a supernatural character who arrived on a Brazilian three-master ship.
Le Horla is by this French author of Boule de Suif ("BOOL duh SWEEF") and The Necklace.

Maupassant once wrote a letter about his mental illness to this other author, whose stories include "A Simple Heart." This author described Frédéric Moreau's ("moh-ROW'S") pursuit of Madame Arnoux ("ar-NOO") in A Sentimental Education.

bonuses.leadin: Charles Anderson Dana left his post as editor for this man's newspaper to serve as Assistant Secretary of War during the Civil War. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this man, who sent George Smalley to cover the Battle of Antietam. This man founded the New York Tribune.
Newspapers were able to quickly publish sensational Civil War stories thanks to this invention. Soldiers used Morse code on this invention to communicate across the battlefield.
A newspaper casualty list prompted Walt Whitman to serve as a nurse at this battle's site of Chatham Manor. Ambrose Burnside's disastrous retreat following this battle was known as the "Mud March".

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, identify the following about the extensive art collections of multinational corporations.
answers: United Kingdom [or UK; or Great Britain; accept England]
parts: In 2010, Commerzbank of Germany sold one of this Swiss artist's thin, bronze Walking Man sculptures for 65 million pounds.
In 2020, an airline from this country sold Cool Edge, a painting by an op art pioneer from here named Bridget Riley. This country is home to the Tate Modern.
The art collection of the Monte dei Paschi bank in this city dates back to 1472. This city's Palazzo Pubblico contains Ambrogio Lorenzetti's Allegory of Good and Bad Government.

bonuses.leadin: Qazi ("kah-zi") Mullah led a state in this mountain range that was invaded during the Murid War. For 10 points each:
answers: harems [or seraglios; or serail; or saray-i-duhteran]
parts: Name this mountain range, where the Naqshbandi Sufi leader Imam Shamil led resistance to foreign occupation. The Circassian ethnic group is from this mountain range.
Due to their supposed beauty, many Circassian women lived in this part of the imperial household reserved for women. This term also refers to the group of concubines surrounding a ruler.

The qizilbash ("kih-zihl-bahsh"), a group of militant Shiites based out of Azerbaijan, helped found this Iranian dynasty. The qizilbash helped this dynasty's founder Ismail I defeat the Aq Qoyunlu ("koh-yoon-loo").
